1) Swansea 5-1 Leeds , Division One, 29/08/1991

The greatest opening-day performance in English football history came from a Welsh team. Swansea, in the top flight for the first time in their 69-year history, hosted a Leeds side who, though they would be relegated that season, had finished in the top half the previous year and had a decent reputation. And Swansea tore them a new one.
Highlights came thick and fast, as they tend to when you win 5-1. There was Bob Latchford's dummy for Swansea's opening goal; Latchford's nine-minute hat-trick on debut after his move from Everton; the swaggering, shoulder-dropping majesty of Alan Curtis's fifth goal; and a commentator who could barely have been more partisan had he started tearfully singing Delilah while gazing longingly at a picture of Nerys Hughes. Listen to the way his voice drops when Leeds equalise. Still, it was the only low note all day.

2) Aston Villa 3-1 Manchester United, Premiership, 19/08/1995

Let's take real good care of a couple of myths surrounding this one. (If you don't remember the game, it's when Villa ransacked United's kids after Alex Ferguson had sold Paul Ince, Mark Hughes and Andrei Kanchelskis in the summer.)

a) There were a number of reasons United were stuffed besides the obvious fact that they had seven players aged 21 or under in their 14-man squad: injuries and suspensions (Bruce, Cole, Giggs, Cantona and May); a very good Villa side, who would finish fourth; but most of all the fact that Ferguson had one of his last flirtations with a 5-3-2 system that has never worked for him.

b) Alan Hansen's oft ridiculed "you can't win anything with kids" comment was basically right. With the team that played this game, United would have won nothing. As the season progressed, they invariably played only three of their youngsters (Nicky Butt, one of the Nevilles and David Beckham). And the fact that they won the Double was almost exclusively down to the almost superhuman peaks scaled by Peter Schmeichel and Eric Cantona in the final three months of the season.

3) Sheffield Wednesday 2-3 Aston Villa, Division One, 17/08/1991

There was a mob calling for Ron Atkinson's inflated head on a stick long before his analysis of Marcel Desailly. In the summer of 1991, having managed Sheffield Wednesday to promotion and the League Cup, Atkinson said he would be "barmy" to leave "the best job in the world". A week later he did one to Aston Villa. Deliciously, the entirely random fixture computer made Villa's first game a trip back to Hillsborough. Atkinson, smiling like a perma-tanned Judas, seemed immune to the dogs' abuse he was getting, but it looked like Wednesday fans would go home happy when they roared into a 2-0 lead. David Hirst, superior to the similar Alan Shearer at this stage of their careers, swooshed an outrageous goal into the top corner from the angle of the box, and then superbly created the second for Danny Wilson.

But, as the proverb doesn't go, fortune favours the unreconstructed bigot, and Atkinson's Villa got back into the game on the stroke of half-time when Chris Woods flapped the ball on to the head of Cyrille Regis. After half-time, Villa had a collective 'Eureka!' moment and realised that Wednesday's shockingly naive halfway-line offside trap was so ill-conceived that it could have been the work of Baldrick (even worse, it was actually the work of Trevor Francis). Villa took advantage through, first, Dalian Atkinson and then, right at the death, Steve Staunton. It was the ultimate hoof in the weapons cabinet for Wednesday fans, but at least they had the last laugh: they finished third, four places and 15 points above Villa.

4) Arsenal 2-4 Norwich, Premier League, 15/08/1992

If memory serves, Arsenal were the bookies' favourites for the inaugural Premier League title after a storming finish to the previous season. In 1991-92 they were the top scorers in the league; in 1992-93, absurdly, they would be the lowest scorers. But all was well for the first hour, after Steve Bould and Kevin Campbell put them 2-0 up against Norwich, being managed for the first time by Mike Walker.
Then Walker brought on his new signing, Mark Robins, and slowly Norwich began to silence the famous North Bank mural, which had been brought in to improve the Highbury atmosphere. Goals from Robins, David Phillips and Ruel Fox gave Norwich the lead, and then Robins sealed the victory with a superb chip after a mistake from Tony Adams, who dithered, transfixed by the ball, as if it had just morphed into a bottle of Scotch and he was debating whether it was bad form to open it and start swigging in front of 24,030 people. Norwich would have many a celebratory drink that season on the way to their highest-ever position of third.

5) Sampdoria 3-3 Lazio, Serie A, 06/09/1992

Even though Serie A's stock has probably never been higher in this country than it was in the late 80s and early 90s, Channel 4 took a bit of a risk when they bought the rights in 1992. After all, the product was renowned for engaging the cells more than the hairs on the back of the neck. But Channel 4 got massively lucky with two things: the unexpected success of a balding man sat reading the paper (it evokes Mel Brooks's description of Larry David in Curb Your Enthusiasm: 'There is something about this middle-aged bald man that is thrilling'), and the backpass law.

The latter, introduced in 1992, threw defenders into the most hilarious disarray for the first few weeks. It was cold turkey, basically. You could imagine defenders, like Mark Renton in Trainspotting, shouting "I appreciate what you're tryin' to do, I really do … but I just need one more backpass like. I NEED ONE MORE BACKPASS!" In the first five weeks of the previous season, there had been 88 goals from 45 games (1.96 per game); in the first five weeks of 1992-93 there were 159 in 45 games (3.53 per game). Six came in the first live game shown on C4, a 3-3 humdinger between Sven-Goran Eriksson's (and Des Walker's) Sampdoria and Lazio, for whom Beppe Signori scored twice on debut (you can see both goals right at the start of this video). In the space of 90 minutes, an arresting diversion had become must-see TV.

6) Manchester United 4-1 Arsenal, Division One, 19/08/1989

Hope and its antisocial sibling, delusion, are the most prevalent emotions on the opening weekend of the season, and rarely have they embraced as powerfully as on this blissful summer's day in M16. It started with Michael Knighton, who had just agreed to buy Manchester United for – and you'll like this – £10m, showing he was 'a proper fan' by juggling the ball in front of the Stretford End. Then United trounced the champions Arsenal 4-1. In the process, Neil Webb embroidered a splendid debut with a stunning, swirling volley that came within smooching distance of technical perfection. A long-overdue title challenge finally seemed to be on the cards. It was all so intoxicating that even Mike Phelan looked like a star. It wasn't a new season; it was a new era.

Or not. Knighton was soon exposed as a chancer with no money. Webb's career was ruined when he ruptured his Achilles on England duty 18 days later. And United were embroiled in a relegation battle until the start of April. It was all a faux show.

Permit me to expand briefly on why I think gratuitously angering Russia is kind of a bad idea.

We all know China is about to dominate the world, right? If you asked your average person in the street in either America or Britain to name the world's top three powers, you'd probably get: the United States; China; and third, I think most people would say Russia, but you'd likely hear a few Indias and maybe some other choices.

Now consider power in terms of nuclear arsenals. Assuming you haven't checked lately, you may think that by now, China may have about as many nukes as the other great powers.

Ahem. Check this out. China has about 400 suspected nuclear warheads. Russia has at least 12,000 (as does the US).

Granted, 400 is plenty enough, but the point is that we don't want another situation where the world's two greatest nuclear powers are at each other's throats. That wasn't good for either society, let alone for the Cubans and Congolese and Angolans and Guatemalans and lots of other folks.

What we want, instead, is reduction and even, eventually, elimination of all nuclear arsenals. Radical and crazy? It's the official position of well-known Chomsky acolytes Henry Kissinger and George Schultz and Sam Nunn.

If the Bush administration leaves office having ratcheted up US-Russia tension, among its other signal triumphs...well, it'll be par for the course, but yet another disaster.

Having watched just about every one of the 29,500 arrows shot in seven days of archery competition, may I share with you something that has no point. At the Paris Olympics of 1900, there was a poodle-clipping competition. Seriously. A French farmer's wife won gold.

If there is a point it is that obviously the French wanted that particular discipline because they thought they might win a medal. And so it is to this day that certain countries have sports dear to their medal chances. We love a bit of rowing and cycling, it would appear.

But nobody overloads themselves with more expectation than the Koreans (South, but the North quite fancy their prospects, too) do in archery. Their women, until yesterday, had won every gold medal going since 1984 - that's six golds at six Games. To that tally could be added seven more of the other colours, to make it 13 out of all the 18 medals available in individual competition, to say nothing of the team medals, which have been gold all the way.

Today, their tally still looks good: 15 from 21, plus another gold in the team event. But they did not win individual gold, Park Sung-hyun losing her Olympic title to Zhang Juan Juan of China.

In the men's event, the team was successful too, taking gold, but their fortunes in the individual event continue to be, well, ordinary. To the two silvers and one bronze from the last six Games, the Koreans can now add another silver.

That in Korean is 'just a silver.' The world champion of 1993 Park Kyung-mo, on his 33rd birthday here in Beijing, lost in the final to Viktor Ruban of the Ukraine. He was doing fine until, when all before had been 9s and 10s, he dropped his penultimate arrow into the 8 ring.

It was close - 113-112 - but, let's face it, it didn't satisfy the Koreans' craving for bow and arrow glory. A haul of two golds, two silvers and a bronze is a rancid dog of a collection.

The Koreans take their archery seriously enough to send their best on sentry duty in the demilitarised zone between them and their neighbours to the north, supposedly to improve powers of concentration. They fill stadiums and hurl abuse at the archers as they are about to shoot, to improve focus.

But it appears the Chinese have moved ahead in the game of not flinching under duress. Stories are leaking out of live snakes inserted into the shirts of archers as they take their positions on the shooting line.

It all explains why the British did not have a good archery week. Until the members of Royal Leamington Spa Archery Club are prepared to step forward with ferrets up their trousers, we shall remain off target.

Or maybe we should just make trouser-ferreting an Olympic sport. Or bring back the poodles.

Not hard to swallow ... Sam Rockwell (right) and Brad William Henke in Choke

This tantalising, somewhat x-rated promo has been around for a little while now, but what with the fact that it keeps getting pulled from YouTube, while the version on the official website seems to be impossible to access, we haven't felt the time was quite right to draw your attention to it.

I was lucky enough to catch a preview of Choke earlier this week, which was followed by a Q&A with author Chuck Palahniuk. The man who created Tyler Durden told the audience that he felt first-time writer-director Clark Gregg's movie was a superior work to his original tome, which he himself describes as a loose sequel to Fight Club.

Choke returns to the world of support groups, but this time the central protagonist is sex addict Vincent Mancini (a career-defining turn from Sam Rockwell) who doesn't seem to be trying very hard to rid himself of his terrible affliction. Mancini, who works as a colonial theme park tour guide, has a former wild-child mother (Angelica Huston) in a mental institution who always thinks he's someone else when he visits.

He also discovers part-way through the film that he may actually be the literal son of God. Oh, and he maintains a bizarre scam which involves sticking too much food down his throat at restaurants so that fellow guests are forced to administer the Heimlich manoeuvre (hence the title). He then taps his rescuers for cash to pay his mum's expensive bills.

I think Choke is going to appeal hugely to fans of Fight Club and Palahniuk's books when it hits screens here on November 21. It is to Fight Club what Roger Avary's excellent Rules of Attraction was to American Psycho: lighter in tone but with similar sensibilities and a refreshing switch in style. Have a look at the trailer and let us know what you think.

Rents will fall by up to 10% this year, according to some of Britain's biggest letting agents, as a wave of properties that owners and developers can't sell have started to flood the rental market.

The fall in rents will bring welcome relief to tenants but will squeeze buy-to-let landlords who now face a triple whammy of falling property values, sliding rental income and rising mortgage costs. To add to their misery, the Law Commission this week issued proposals on "encouraging responsible letting" that are likely to drive up administrative costs for landlords.

The forecast fall in rents will bewilder landlords, given that many who would otherwise be buying are sitting out the property market woes by renting instead. Shouldn't that be pushing up rents?

The reality, according to property agents Knight Frank, is that although there is a big rise in the number of people wanting to rent, it has been more than offset by a surge in "forced landlords" who, unable to sell, are now placing properties with letting agents.

Liam Bailey, head of residential research, says rents in the London area peaked in 2007 and will fall 10% this year. "The problem is that the volume of tenants has risen by 25%, but the volume of property available for rent has risen by 35%. There is a lot of stock coming in from people who can't sell and who are putting it on the rental market instead. There is a lot of choice out there for tenants."

Jane Ingram, head of lettings at Savills, says: "Across the UK we are seeing a lot of people choosing to rent rather than buy, and our offices are very busy. But there has also been a surge in stock, and I would say in some areas [rental] prices have fallen by 10%. In Docklands, in particular, we are seeing an oversupply. Developers have decided not to sell and are putting properties through the lettings market."

Knight Frank and Savills have a strong bias towards higher-priced lets in London and the south-east, but in the rest of the UK there is growing evidence of a wider slide in rents. According to the Gumtree 2008 rental index issued this week, average rents over the past year have fallen by 0.9% in Leeds, 2.7% in Manchester and 3.5% in Birmingham. However, not all surveys suggest rents are under pressure. Buy-to-let lender Paragon says that, in the past year, rents have risen by 9.3%.

Many amateur buy-to-let landlords who poured into the market in 2006 and 2007 may be facing huge losses. Hargreaves Lansdown suggested this week nearly 200,000 buy-to-let mortgages taken out in 2007 may be in negative equity as a result of falling house prices, and that 10,000 are in arrears.

"Recent buy-to-let investors may find themselves facing a 90% capital loss if they borrowed 90% of their property value," says Laith Khalaf of Hargreaves Lansdown. "Property investors may be forced to sell up prematurely because interest payments become unaffordable. The real test of affordability is to come in 2009/10 when those who borrowed large sums at relatively cheap rates in 2007 come off two and three-year fixed deals."

Zoe Mernick, 24, this week rented a flat in Clapham, south London, which the owner had spent months trying to sell. When hunting for a flat, she found many "forced landlords" had unrealistic expectations about rents. "We've seen flats with no kitchens and not even enough space for a packet of breakfast cereal - they assume you only need a microwave and a freezer. Lots had no storage space for clothes, and there was one where the second bedroom was separated from the rest of the flat by a curtain. Some have been overpriced by as much as £500 a month, because that's what they need to pay the mortgage."

Her flatmate, Sarah Brewer, says: "Estate agents tell us they have to follow landlords' instructions even if they are ridiculous. Landlords just aren't adjusting to the market."

One of the reasons why Labour politicians find it hard to attack David Cameron is because they can't agree what he represents.

Is he closet Thatcherite? A paternalistic toff? A "shallow salesman", who does not really believe in anything? Or, as David Miliband said in his Guardian article last month, "a politician of the status quo - a status quo he consistently voted against".

None of these answers has been entirely convincing. But this week the Institute for Public Policy Research published an article in its journal Public Policy Research that attempts to solve the puzzle of what Cameron actually stands for.

It's by Richard Reeves, who has just been appointed as director of Demos. It's not available online, but here are his key conclusions.

The first point - and this is bad news for Labour - is that Cameron is not a fake.

"Cameronism is real - as real as New Labour, or the Third Way - and is likely to be the guiding light of the next government," writes Reeves.

(This may seem obvious - unless you want to get sidetracked into an argument about whether New Labour or the Third Way were real - but I think there are plenty of Labour ministers who still do not really believe it.)

As for what Cameronism actually is, Reeves thinks we are now in a position to know the answer.

"Cameronism is certainly not an ideology, nor even - yet - a coherent political philosophy. Cameron himself, in his Keith Joseph lecture, explicitly rejected 'ideological' politics, in favour of 'practical conservatism'. But the broad contours of his thinking, and that of the bright politicians and advisers around him, are now visible. Cameron is asking hard questions about Labour's record, and the state of the nation. But he is asking tough questions of himself too, which have to be answered before his party can be considered fit for government.

"Cameronism displays a number of key features: it emphasises the pragmatic over the theoretical; takes an essentially optimistic view of human nature; favours the devolution, rather than the centralisation, of power; stresses social, rather than economic, progress; and places more faith in society than the state."

Reeves also quotes a line from a speech Cameron delivered this year that he describes as "the best summary of Cameronism Cameron himself has yet articulated". It's the line where Cameron said: "We want to respond to what should be a new post-bureaucratic age, by decentralising power, by giving people more opportunity and control over their lives, by making families stronger and society more responsible."

Reeves says, although people have in the past tended to exaggerate the differences between the main political parties, "the level of political disorientation caused by Cameronism is still difficult to cope with". He believes Cameronism represents "genuine radicalism".

The article is mostly positive. It is based on what Cameron and his allies have said and written (rather than on how they voted a few years ago) and it doesn't address the awkward issue of how much support there is for Cameronism within the Conservative party as a whole (which could turn out to be where the Tories are vulnerable).

But Reeves is not uncritical. He says Cameron wants to create a "responsible society" by encouraging better behaviour, but he questions whether this is really feasible.

"There is more than a hint here, in Jon Elster's phrase, of Cameron 'willing that which cannot be willed'. Cameron wants to 'roll forward society', but it is not yet clear how this can be achieved, and doubtful it can be achieved unless the Conservatives move to a more balanced view of the state.

"Cameron verges on hypocrisy on the issue of state action. He has set up a Young Adult Trust, which he says is 'working in partnership with many of Britain's leading youth organisations to develop plans for all 16-year-olds that help teach them the responsibilities of adulthood'.

"A national programme to teach adulthood? If Ed Balls announced it, the Tories would be turning it into a piece of 'nanny state gone mad' propaganda. Cameron is quite right that Labour is very often guilty of knee-jerk statism, but he is equally at risk of unthinking anti-statism."

I'm not sure this is much use to the poor soul who has the job of coming up with a strategy for Labour to win the next election. But at least it probably helps to understand what you're up against.

Bradley Wiggins began his defence of his Olympic 4,000m title on the Laoshan velodrome in the most emphatic style possible, breaking his own Olympic record with a time of 4min 15.031sec on the Laoshan velodrome. He will be virtually impossible to dislodge in tomorrow's rounds, with the only man on the track to approach his time the New Zealander Hayden Roulston.

The reigning world champion across his three disciplines, the 28-year-old Londoner is bidding to take three Olympic gold medals in the five days of track competition, beginning with the individual pursuit, continuing with the team event on Sunday and Monday before contesting the Madison with Mark Cavendish on Tuesday.

In his qualifier, Wiggins was up against the world championship bronze medallist Alexei Markov of Russia, the pair starting on opposite sides of the track and "pursuing" each other for the distance. Wiggins started steadily but was the fastest man on the track after two kilometres, by which time it was clear that he was within Olympic record pace.

Riding with the implacable rhythm of a metronome, Wiggins never faltered and as the third kilometre approached he had Markov in his sights. By the finish they were in the same straight and the Briton was in total control.

Wiggins will face the slowest qualifier, Alexandr Serov of Russia in tomorrow morning's second round, which will in turn decide the line-ups for the finals, with the fastest four going through to ride-offs for gold and silver, bronze and fourth.

Wiggins's 20-year-old team-mate Steven Burke made his Olympic debut in fine style, catching his opponent Carlos Alzate of Colombia with two laps remaining to finish in 4min 22.260sec, knocking nine seconds off his personal best for the distance. He qualified in fifth place and will race against Volodymyr Dyudya of the Ukraine tomorrow morning.

In the biggest upset of the evening, the silver medallist at the Manchester world championships, Jenning Huizinga of the Netherlands was overhauled in the third kilometre by Roulston, finishing in a surprisingly slow 4min 37.097sec in spite of using a curious aerodynamic position, with his hands up in front of his face.

"Oh would some power the giftie gie us, to see ourselves as others see us," wrote Robert Burns in To a Louse. But democratically elected governments face incessant scrutiny. So it is unusual to see one exposing itself voluntarily to the glare of critical inspection. But that is what the British government did when it submitted its report to the United Nations' committee on human rights under section 40 of the international covenant on civil and political rights. The committee's conclusions offer insights that should intrigue all who care about freedom of speech.

The UN is concerned that the application of the law of libel in English courts has "served to discourage critical media reporting on matters of serious public interest". It is referring to the chilling effect of the phenomenon known as libel tourism, which has allowed powerful interests to obstruct the publication abroad of books and articles by suing for libel in English courts.

In 2004 the Saudi investment banker Khalid bin Mahfouz won a default defamation judgment in the high court against the American academic Rachel Ehrenfeld over allegations contained in her 2003 book Funding Evil: How Terrorism is Financed. At the time of the trial the book had sold only 23 copies in the UK. Ehrenfeld described the process of libel tourism exploited in that case as "a form of intellectual terrorism". Her American lawyers called it part of the most important challenge to free speech in the past 50 years.

That same year another author, Craig Unger, had publication of his book House of Bush: House of Saud: The secret relationship between the world's two most powerful dynasties, scrapped in the UK. His publishers were concerned that the Saudi Royal family would use British libel law to sue for damages.

British lawyers and politicians have paid little attention to the points of principle at stake. They should wake up, not least because the internet now means that material published in one country can be deemed to be nigh universally available. In these circumstances libel tourism has the potential to turn English courts into censorship enforcement agencies for litigants with secrets to hide and money to burn. It poses a wholly unacceptable threat to academic freedom and freedom of speech.

The UN committee is also critical of the Official Secrets Act 1989 on the grounds that it can be used to prevent whistleblowing by former public servants. The case of David Shayler, the former MI5 agent, is one such example. Shayler was sentenced to six months' imprisonment under sections 1 and 4 of the act after writing about the activities of the security services in the Mail on Sunday.

The 1989 act was designed to improve the 1911 version which banned publication of details as arcane as the brand of crockery used in the Home Office unless its release was authorised. It is helpful to be reminded that the revised legislation remains potentially oppressive. There is no public interest defence for civil servants who leak information about what the government is doing in our name. The House of Lords confirmed this in the Shayler case.

So, does Britain stand condemned as a haven for censorship, secrecy and oppression? The picture is not so stark. The failings highlighted by members of the UN committee were carefully identified for them by diligent British civil servants. Bravo ladies and gentlemen. And now that you have offered ministers the blessing Robert Burns prized, we journalists must do our duty to the public sphere by maintaining pressure on them to liberalise the law.

Should George Bush feel vindicated in his decision to invade Iraq five years ago, now that the situation in Iraq - particularly Basra - is improving?

No doubt as he leaves the White House, Bush will argue that a more stable Iraq justifies his decision to topple Saddam Hussein. The US president is bound to repeat the mantra that the world is better off without Saddam. The dramatisation House of Saddam is a useful reminder of what a nasty piece of work he was, not to mention his pathological elder son, Uday.

The debate is more than academic, as Iraq represents a clear division between the two US presidential hopefuls. Barack Obama opposed the war from the start, as well as the surge, while his Republican rival, John McCain, backed the surge and is more inclined to give Bush the benefit of the doubt on invading in the first place.

But one leading US commentator is adamant the costs of invading Iraq have outweighed any benefits. Francis Fukuyama of End of History fame wrote in the Wall Street Journal yesterday:

"By invading Iraq in the manner it did, the US exacerbated all of the threats it faced prior to 2003. Recruitment into terrorist cells shot up all over the world. North Korea and Iran accelerated their development of nuclear weapons. Iran has emerged as the dominant regional power in the Persian Gulf once the US removed its major rival from the scene and put its Shi'ite clients into power in Baghdad. While everyone is better off without Saddam Hussein around, the cost was hugely disproportionate. If you don't believe this, ask yourself whether Congress would ever have voted to authorise the war in 2002 if it knew there was no WMD, or that there would be trillion-dollar budget outlays, or that there would be 30,000 dead and wounded after five years of bitter struggle."

Fukuyama then goes on to make the point that after having invaded Iraq, the US does not have much of a leg to stand on in "trying to rally opposition to Russia on the basis of international law and norms constraining the strong from using force against the weak".

Interestingly, this neo-conservative goes on to throw his vote behind Obama rather than McCain because the Democrat does not share "McCain's instinctive reliance on hard power as the primary instrument for dealing with messy questions of terrorism and proliferation in the broader Middle East".

Today's findings that people over 50 are experiencing shortfalls in the quality of care offered by the NHS in England have highlighted fears that doctors care more about conditions where assessments earned them extra money.

If you are suffering from heart disease, diabetes and high blood pressure, it seems you are in luck. If your problem is osteoarthritis, incontinence and osteoporosis, it seems you may have to carry on suffering.

Age Concern's Gordon Lishman claims: "The rewards system for GPs to treat particular conditions has worked - but this hasn't included health problems older people particularly suffer from like depression, falls, and vision and hearing problems."

This week, the charity has launched national campaign to improve the lives of older people with depression - but it may have more unhappy people to worry about if today's survey findings fail to spark improvements.

Kate Jopling of Help the Aged comments "These depressing results show that, when it comes to healthcare, all too often older people and the conditions that affect them come far down the pecking order.

"This kind of ageist treatment is precisely why legislation against age discrimination is needed."

And the Arthritis Research Campaign claims: "We know that many older people with osteoarthritis are often fobbed off by GPs and told: 'It's your age you've got to live with it', rather than being offered practical advice on weight loss, exercise and pain relief, or a referral to see a physiotherapist."

The Department of Health has investigated the problem; in June it issued a report Research on eliminating age discrimination in social services and mental health services, but today's report from the University of East Anglia suggests much more work is required.

Have you come across age discrimination in health treatment? Or are you in one of the patches where levels of care have been found to be acceptable?

The 46th Bundesliga season kicks off tonight with Bayern v Hamburg and the competition is guaranteed to be bigger and, ahem, bigger than ever: 172 countries will carry the live-feed from the Allianz Arena, up from – oh yes – 171 last year round. (You wonder which new country the Bundesliga suits managed to cajole into signing up. Tuvalu? St. Kitts and Nevis? Andorra? It's probably Kosovo. They didn't officially exist yet last year)

Attendance figures are set to rise again thanks to the return of FC Köln and Borussia Mönchengladbach, two proper sides with big stadiums. Most clubs are even run profitably. All would be rosy and lovely in the Bundesliga garden if it weren't for Bernhard Heitzer, the new bête noire of German football. Heitzer, an avid fan himself, is the president of the German competition commission, a public body that has caused the clubs endless grief this summer. The commission has looked into the league's proposed €2.5bn (£1.98bn) TV deal for 2009-10 to 2014-15 and found it unacceptable. They argued that centralised marketing by the clubs, a de-facto cartel, could only be justified if the consumer benefited materially. They went on to define that benefit quite narrowly: a free-to-air highlight show before 8pm has to remain an intrinsic part of the Bundesliga TV schedule (We get all the games and goals from 6.30pm at the moment). In a snide aside, Heitzer noted English pay-tv consumers paid roughly four times as much as Germans, for less than half of all the games. "But the results of their national team in the big competitions don't seem to have been helped by the blessings of high pay-tv income at all," he sniggered gratuitously.

The league are in shock because the commission's opinion amounts to a law proscribing early evening MOTD-type coverage by public broadcasters at the expense of Premiere, the sole pay-tv channel. Even without Alan Shearer in the studio, it's a bit of a nightmare scenario, because the value of the rights will naturally decrease. "The [commission] abuses the league and endangers professional football in Germany with their intervention", said angry league-CEO Christian Seifert, "it's a populist decision, paradoxically designed to decrease competition rather than to increase it." Insiders feel Heitzer has been secretly spurred on to adopt this stance by the German government. The situation is further complicated by the bigger teams' conflict of interest. They'd be the first ones to benefit from de-centralised marketing: Bayern's rights are said to be worth €100m (£79.4m) alone, more than three times as much as they're currently getting. Officially, they support the egalitarian status quo but they could well be the real winners of this contest.

Rest assured that there will be a 47th season next year. Some sort of compromise will be reached eventually, in the classic Bundesrepublik Deutschland style.

The best thing about this tedious tale was the fact that it made up for a distinct lack of tedious transfer tales this summer. Champions Bayern only brought in veteran keeper Hans-Jörg Butt as Michael Rensing's understudy – they don't really trust the 24-year-old between the sticks and might well go for a bigger name in the winter – and Werder Bremen's reassuringly haughty midfielder Tim Borowski, both on a free. "Our squad is good enough", said new manager Jürgen Klinsmann, "if we had two more players, it would be difficult to keep everyone happy". Maybe that's why Bayern made both Mathieu Flamini and Gennaro Gattuso offers they could refuse and saw their €25m (19.8m) bid for Stuttgart's Mario Gómez turned down.

Of course Klinsmann himself has really been the biggest signing for the Bavarians, as he's brought a bus-load of coaches, assistants, scouts and fitness experts with him to the Säbenerstrasse. He's also placed some Buddha figurines and white sun beds on the roof terrace of the new training ground complex to create a "wellness oasis", as Karl-Heinz Rummenigge described it, in an unintentionally mid-90s boutique hotel retro-style.

Hamburg, their opponents tonight, are still smarting from Rafael van der Vaart's predictable €16m defection to Real Madrid, a "dream move" for the 25-year-old. "He was the best Hamburg player for 25 years," said manager Martin Jol. The northerners will have to get one or two very decent replacements in before the end of the month, otherwise contesting the Uefa Cup places will be the extent of their ambitions.

Their rivals Schalke also have a new Dutch coach, Fred Rutten. The ex-Twente Enschede doesn't quite have as strong a Dutch accent as his successor Steve McClaren, but he's got Orlando Engelaar instead: the lanky Holland midfielder who followed him to Gelsenkirchen. Schalke will, in all likelihood, make it 50 years without a championship this season. They should be useful side, however, new striker Jefferson Farfán's shoulder injury notwithstanding.

Bremen, meanwhile, are trying hard to rescue Claudio Pizarro from his sad life in London's night-clubs, they'll need at least one more good striker to be serious contenders. Both Stuttgart and Felix Magath's Wolfsburg will also push for a Champions League place but the perhaps biggest story of the year will be the incongruous rise of TSG 1899 Hoffenheim. 3,300 people live in that tiny city, but 13,300 have bought season-tickets – the whole region wants to be part of the Bundesliga's first ever start-up venture. Billionaire Dietmar Hopp started providing financial backing to his former team, a non-descript amateur outfit playing in the A-Klasse (the seventh league) in 1990. Six promotions later, Ralf Rangnick's side have already started to frighten the established order with some smart Brazilian buys and a youth academy system modelled on Arsenal. Hopp's not quite Roman Abramovich, but he's the first big spending president this league's ever had. There'll plenty of hard feelings and jealousy; and some decent football in the bargain. It should all be terribly emotional as well.

Watch out Kosovo – here we come.

It's complicated, so concentrate. Carolijn Brouwer, the world sailor of the year 10 years ago, was born in Leiden in the Netherlands, for whom she sailed at both the 2000 and 2004 Olympics in Sydney and Athens. But this time she is representing Belgium because her former boyfriend, Belgian Sebastien Godefroid, is in the same boat - literally.

Brouwer chose to switch nationalities although the Dutch were keen to have Godefroid on board flying their colours in the Tornado class. However Brouwer figured her chances of pursuing a gold would be better served under the Belgian flag. So Dutch or Belgian? "I'm both", she says and is treated as "one of the blokes" by Tornado sailors, although the men "don't like me beating them".

And here is where the complications really kick in, for although Brouwer and Godefroid remain the best of sailing mates, Carolijn has since switched her affairs of the heart to Australian Darren Bundock, the six times world champion and her fiancée, who will be sailing against her in a pairing with Glenn Ashby - expected to be one of the leading challengers for Tornado gold.

"It's hard," admitted Brouwer, who finished second in the world championships last year. "Between Seb and me there is history and obviously I'm now with Darren. We hadn't planned it this way. These are things that just happen and you cannot control it. Darren is pretty quiet and laid back, and concentrates on his own thing. We have both been around the sport a long time, and just leave each other in peace. I'm happy to be sailing for Belgium. I'll always be grateful to the Dutch for the support they have given me. But this is a natural thing to be happening in sport nowadays."

After making its debut in the Montreal Games 32 years ago, this will be the last appearance of the multi-hull Tornado class - a catamaran competition where men and women can race alongside each other on an even basis - at the Olympics. "I think this will be my last Olympics, not so much because I think I'm getting old and should stop, but because there is just no other option for me," Brouwer said. "It's a shame because I would really have loved to have done another four years."

The law governing how lapdancing clubs are licensed needs to be changed to make it harder for them to open in unsuitable locations, council leaders said today.

The local government association released a letter it has sent to ministers saying that lapdancing clubs should be treated as "sex encounter establishments" for licensing purposes.

At the moment, under the Licensing Act 2003, lapdancing clubs are in the same category as bars and cafes. But that means councils are not allowed to consider the kind of customers they might attract, or the suitability to a location, when deciding whether or not to issue a licence.

"The new licensing laws were intended to give local people more of a say on how pubs and clubs are run in their area, but when it comes to lapdancing establishments councils often find there is little they can do to respond to people's wishes," Sir Jeremy Beecham, the vice chairman of the LGA, said in the letter.

The letter was released to the media on the day a government consultation on the issue comes to a close.

In June, licensing minister Gerry Sutcliffe wrote to every council in England and Wales for their views on the licensing of lapdancing clubs.

The LGA said that there are now around 300 lapdancing clubs in Britain, around double the number there were in 2003. Council leaders want them included in the same licensing category as sex shops and sex cinemas under the Local Government (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1982 - venues where nude entertainment is provided for the purpose of sexual stimulation.

Object and the Fawcett Society, groups which both campaign for women's rights, have called for legislation to close this loophole to be introduced in the coming parliamentary session.

Object's director Dr Sasha Rakoff said: "Many local authorities have added their voice to growing calls for an end to licensing of lapdancing clubs as cafes.

"Current licensing has acted as a floodgate to the industry whilst making it difficult for local authorities and local people to have a say in this process.

"It has helped normalise la dancing clubs and attitudes that encourage seeing women as sex objects, not people.

"The solution to this problem does not lie in tinkering with the Licensing Act 2003 or in planning controls. The solution lies in licensing lapdancing clubs for what they are: venues that provide visual entertainment for sexual stimulation - in other words, sex encounter establishments.

"We call on the government to restore democracy to the licensing process and send out a powerful message that buying a lapdance is not the same as buying a cappuccino."

Fawcett Society campaigns officer Kat Banyard added: "A lax licensing regime has led to the proliferation of lapdancing clubs in UK.

"Straitjacketed by the Licensing Act 2003, local authorities have been powerless to stop the spread.

"They are compelled to license lapdance clubs like cafes - despite having a very different social impact.

"Lapdance clubs fuel a sexist culture of treating women as sex objects. Areas surrounding lapdance clubs can become 'no-go' areas for women.

"The only viable solution is to license lapdancing clubs as sex encounter establishments."

Whose idea was it?

The identity-card plan has a long history. Michael Howard was in favour in his days as home secretary in the 1990s and, when Labour came to power, Jack Straw floated that idea of a "citizen's access card".

After the September 11 attacks in 2001, David Blunkett, the then-home secretary, began to promote it heavily, although it took him some time to persuade his cabinet colleagues.

What are the cards supposed to achieve?

Home secretaries such as Howard and Blunkett have been attracted to identity cards as a weapon in the fight against crime, and some police organisations are in favour on these grounds too. It has been argued that identity cards could help the authorities target terrorists, serious criminals using false identities, welfare fraudsters and illegal immigrants.

But the government now puts far less emphasis on this argument, partly because the terrorists involved in 9/11 and 7/7 were not using false identities and partly because cards would only work as anti-crime devices if they were compulsory, which raises another problem altogether (see below).

Increasingly ministers now argue that identity cards will serve as a consumer facility for people who need to prove their identity when opening bank accounts, etc.

What powers does the government have?

The main enabling legislation, the Identity Cards Act, went through parliament two years ago and is now law. But it gave ministers considerable discretion as to how they implement the scheme. Gordon Brown has also said that parliament will vote before the introduction of a compulsory scheme.

What does the scheme involve?

More than just having a bit of plastic. The identity card itself would be linked to a national identity database which would contain dozens of pieces of information, such as photographs, national insurance numbers, dates of birth and addresses. It would also include biometric information – fingerprints.

When will they come in?

Foreigners from outside the EU will need to register their biometric details from later this year. From 2009 the scheme will be extended to people working in high-risk areas, such as airports. From 2010 they will be offered to students. And from 2011 they will be offered to people renewing their passports.

Why students?

The government believes that they will be attracted by the idea of having identity cards because, as they open bank accounts and rent property, they have a particular need to be able to prove their identity.

Will the cards be compulsory?

They will be for non-EU migrants and for workers in high-risk areas. For British citizens they will not exactly be compulsory, but it will be impossible to get a passport without putting your details on the database, so, in practice, for anyone wanting to travel abroad, they will be.

Will the database be safe?

That depends who you believe. The government says that the information will only be accessible to "highly security-cleared individuals". But the recent security lapses with data have highlighted how easy it is for things to go wrong and today's revelations about the problems with fingerprints for those over the age of 75 have illustrated another potential problem.

Mickey Rourke in 2005. Photo: Francois Guillot/AFP/Getty Image

Little so warms the soul as a genuine, copper-bottomed comeback story. All the more cheering, therefore, to find buzz building among the blogs that we may shortly be witnessing two for the price of one - each emerging in a cloud of steroidal rage via The Wrestler, a tale of mayhem in the ring directed by Darren Aronofsky and starring Mickey Rourke.

It is, let's face it, a marriage of material, film-maker and actor so implausible a moment of silent pause might be advisable just to digest it. And yet, having sailed into the programmes of several of this autumn's festivals, the Playlist among others has begun to suspect there may be just be a triumph waiting to be discovered beneath the (vast) curiosity factor. And for whatever it might be worth, my own instinct here agrees - I peer at the still of a bloodied, metal-haired Rourke reeling against the ropes (craftsmanlike detail: a placard in the crowd reading "Necrobutcher sucks a fat dick"), and somehow, the entire thing clicks into place.

Aronofsky alone is, of course, a second act waiting to happen; the New York wunderkind who broke through with his pristine debut Pi and operatic follow-up Requiem for a Dream before wasting all momentum on fruitless attempts to jump-start what would later (in the hands of Christopher Nolan) become the re-tooled Batman franchise. After still more frustration, he finally made The Fountain, a lumbering exercise in metaphysical sci-fi that should have been sub-titled The Career Killer. For an obvious talent with a large commercial black mark beside his name, hobbled by his compulsion to expand the language of cinema every time he ordered coffee, The Wrestler seemed at first pure industry penance: a real-life echo of the fate of the Coens' Barton Fink, tasked by his studio paymasters with writing a lunk-headed grappling picture ("there's plenty of poetry right inside that ring, Fink").

Bad vibes were not dispelled by news the project was to star Nicolas Cage, a performer in who no amount of garish spandex could disguise an ever-more dislikable hangdog pomposity. But through the mysteries of A-list career strategies, Aronofsky was delivered a priceless gift when Cage almost instantly dropped out - and the central role instead fell to Rourke.

For with that one turn of events, what appeared a disaster-in-the-making now made absolute sense. A director too smart for his own good would return to the kind of traditional narrative that, for all their aesthetic jiggery-pokery, both his first two movies had quietly relied on - with an actor who had surely now found the role he was born to play. A crazed variant of the Rocky blueprint, shacked up not with the saintly Adrian but an aging stripper, risking a fatal heart attack for the fabled one last fight, old and scarred-up and staggering on... it all fits Rourke so flawlessly it seems bizarre not so much that Cage was cast ahead of him, but that any other actor could have been.

His mid-80s stardom derailed by bad decisions and unworthy behaviour before the long wilderness years of cosmetic surgery and small dog ownership, Rourke's own deeply baroque biography is the perfect match for the supersized lunacy of pro wrestling, his comeback as a leading man a mirror held up to the part itself. And yet, more importantly, in Rourke the film also acquired a figure who can act the guts out of a movie. For all the kitsch-machismo, when the mood or the material takes him, I'm not sure there are many other actors in film today who can mine quite the same seam of corrosive regret and shambling self-knowledge (if you don't believe me, check out his film-stealing one-minute cameo in Sean Penn's The Pledge, or every second of Barfly).

Possessed of a personal back story beyond the most over-heated scriptwriter and the ability to almost casually stroll off with a film, though I'm not sure he'd thank me for saying it, Mickey Rourke is pretty much everything I like about Hollywood. As such, I can't wait for The Wrestler; and frankly, anyone who wishes to take issue with that can go and join the Necrobutcher.

Another gold for Phelps

This time Phelps, the man whose pancakes and pizza diet is an inspiration to lorry drivers everywhere, took the 200m individual medley in a time of 1:54.23 to earn him his sixth medal of the Games. Elsewhere, the Americans finally won gold in the gymnastics. But it was not All-American girl and world champion Shawn Johnson who won the women's individual all-round, but her room-mate Nastia Liukin. When asked how she felt, Liukin, whose father and coach Valeri won two gold medals for the Soviets in Seoul and whose mother, Anna Kotchneva, was world rhythmic gymnastic champion, admitted she was in "shock" - along with many of the crowd in the National Indoor arena at the sight of a non-Chinese winner.

Meanwhile the athletics is under way. Kelly Sotherton began her attempt
to win a second Olympic medal with a lifetime best in the 100m hurdles before faltering in the high jump (see below), but most people's eyes were on the Bird's Nest where the 100m heats got under way. There were few surprises as Asafa Powell shrugged off a stomach upset to join Usain Bolt, Tyson Gay and the particularly impressive Tyrone Edgar in the second round - unless you count Britain's Craig Pickering (10.21) and Simeon Williamson (10.42) also making it through.

People aged 50 and over, but especially the old and frail, are not receiving basic standards of healthcare, according to new research.

Experts found shortfalls in the quality of care offered by the NHS and private providers to patients with conditions such as osteoarthritis, incontinence and osteoporosis.

But they found that doctors paid particular attention to conditions where assessments earned them extra money, including heart disease, diabetes and high blood pressure.

Dr Nick Steel, the senior lecturer in primary care at the University of East Anglia, who led the study, said: "One of the conditions that came out worst was osteoarthritis, where we asked people if they'd received basic advice such as doing exercises to control the condition, and whether they had effective pain relief.

"At the more severe end of the scale, for those with severe osteoarthritis, we asked if they had been given the opportunity to see a specialist to talk about joint replacement.

"There were also issues around whether elderly patients had been asked the reason for their falls. These types of areas did not fare so well in the study."

The research, published in the British Medical Journal, found the quality of healthcare for people with common health conditions "varied substantially by condition".

Scores on the quality of care ranged from 83% for heart disease to 29% for osteoarthritis.

Overall, only 62% of the care recommended for people aged 50 and over is actually received in England, the research found.

The study, which involved 8,688 people, examined 13 different health conditions including heart disease, diabetes, stroke, depression and osteoarthritis.

A series of questionnaires and face-to-face interviews were used and the findings assessed against a series of markers on the quality of care, approved by a medical panel.

These included established guidelines on managing conditions, comparable to those issued by the National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (Nice).

The researchers found substantially more care was provided for general medical conditions (74%) than for geriatric conditions (57%), including falls, osteoarthritis, urinary incontinence, cataract problems, hearing problems and osteoporosis.

Conditions that come under the Quality and Outcomes Framework (QOF) - which give incentives to GPs - received better attention. In 75% of such cases, people got the right treatment.

Steel said it could not be concluded that care for people with conditions outside the QOF had got worse, but it was not improving in line with conditions included in GPs' contracts.

People were far more likely to receive screening and preventative care (80%) than treatment and follow-up care (64%) or diagnostic care (60%), the study found.

The authors concluded: "Shortfalls in receipt of basic recommended care by adults aged 50 or more with common health conditions in England were most noticeable in areas associated with disability and frailty, but few areas were exempt.

"Efforts to improve care have substantial scope to achieve better health outcomes and particularly need to include chronic conditions that affect quality of life of older people."

Gordon Lishman, the director general of Age Concern, said: "These figures show that age discrimination within the NHS is still rife.

"The rewards system for GPs to treat particular conditions has worked - but this hasn't included health problems older people particularly suffer from like depression, falls, and vision and hearing problems.

Kate Jopling, the head of public affairs at Help the Aged, said: "These depressing results show that, when it comes to healthcare, all too often older people and the conditions that affect them come far down the pecking order.

"This kind of ageist treatment is precisely why legislation against age discrimination is needed.

"The government has announced this will form part of the forthcoming equality bill but no timeframe or process has been agreed - until that happens, older people will continue to be short changed by the health service."

A spokeswoman for the Arthritis Research Campaign said: "We know that many older people with osteoarthritis are often fobbed off by GPs and told: 'It's your age you've got to live with it', rather than being offered practical advice on weight loss, exercise and pain relief, or a referral to see a physiotherapist.

"Standards of care vary enormously around the country and it's simply unacceptable."

The Department of Health said: "Older people have a right to high quality care, regardless of their age.

"It is unacceptable for them to be treated any differently. Our recent Darzi review sets out a framework for improving the quality of care for everybody that uses the NHS.

"A lot of progress has been made already with the treatment and care of older people but we recognise more can be done.

"We have recently started work on providing an increased focus on preventative care for older people. The prevention package will include an expert group to help the NHS better provide services for falls, fractures and osteoporosis."

America has a new public enemy – oil speculators. The public is not happy with the sky-high cost of a tank of petrol and anybody responsible for ratcheting up prices is considered worthy of a good kicking.

People are willing to vent their fury on anybody – even on a mild-mannered bunch of regulatory bureaucrats.

The Federal Trade Commission has asked for views on proposed fines of up to $1m per day for anybody caught manipulating the market for oil, gas or other petrochemical products. Responses from the public, which are posted on the commission's website, are illuminating.

"It just boggles my mind how the US government can sit back and let us be effectively raped at the pumps," thunders a West Virginia man, Jeremy Bradley. "How long is this going to be permitted to continue? These leeches are nothing more than a cancer to society."

Joel Poston of Tennessee is similarly vitriolic: "FTC get off your ass and stop sitting there collecting taxpayer dollars and not doing your job. Do it today. Impress us all and cause prices to go back to normal."

A Florida respondent, Brook Paschkes, has a constructive suggestion – why, she asks, doesn't the government give everybody incentives to install solar panels?

Meanwhile in Kansas, Gary Reinecke suspects routine price-fixing: "Here in Wichita, when gas prices go up over night all stations go up in price over night, and they say they don't talk to each other."

The Independent Lubricant Manufacturers' Association is very much in favour of a clampdown on manipulation – and even wants a broadening of the proposed law.

But the oil industry (surprise, surprise) is opposed. The National Petrochemical & Refiners Association, which numbers BP and ExxonMobil among its members, reckons a crackdown on manipulation will impose "regulatory burdens that outweigh any likely benefits". In a dubious bit of hyperbole, it claims legislation to stamp out price manipulation amounts to "government price fixing".

Perhaps the last word should go to an anonymous respondent who wrote to the FTC under the name "secret" to warn: "It is going to end up with killings at the gas stations because people cannot afford gas."

Olympic spirit

An email popped up in my inbox on Friday from a journalist friend in Toronto.
"Are you by any chance watching the Olympic thingy?" he asked, referring to Beijing's lavish opening ceremony. "It's all so beautifully understated ... you'd hardly know the Chinese had anything to do with it."

Actually, I wasn't watching the ceremony - because Americans weren't allowed to watch it live, unlike Canadians, Britons or pretty much any other nationality on the planet.

NBC, which has paid more than $600m for exclusive US broadcasting rights to the Olympics, decided that the opening ceremony was at an inconvenient time because it happened during the morning on America's east coast. So it taped the event and showed it "as live" at peak evening viewing time 12 hours later.

While millions around the world were treated to elaborately choreographed drummers, the lighting of the flame and flag-carrying teams of athletes, Americans were subjected to a media black-out. NBC adopted a stazi-like approach to any websites which tried to break its monopoly.

In a bizarre charade, anchormen from NBC's business offshoot, CNBC, presented part of their morning news show from a camera position outside the Beijing's "bird's nest" stadium but they had to pretend there was nothing going on inside.

Even when a massive fireworks display turned the sky red directly behind them, they kept a straight face and completely ignored the bangs as this marvellous screenshot demonstrates.

It all seems a bit of a shame. Some American viewers were driven to watching Spanish-language coverage of the opening ceremony on obscure cable television channels. NBC might be maximising their advertising revenue but they're not really capturing the Olympic spirit, are they?

Hot and bothered

A blast of good sense from New York's city council which looks set to fine shops which "cool the sidewalk" by leaving their doors wide open and their air conditioning on. It's quite common to see stores wasting energy in this way at the height of the Big Apple's scorching summer. If the bill goes through, first-time offenders will get a warning. Second time, it's a $200 fine and the third time, the cost goes up to $400. Bang to rights.

Hello Sam
[In an accent that falls somewhere between West Country soy-der and pony-club posh, with just a hint of Montreal twang thrown in] Hello, Small Talk.

Right, let's get this out of the way early doors - have you ever met, been in the same room as, or had anything ever to do with, Zara Phillips?
Yes I have.

And what's she like?
She's very good fun.

Are you ever fed up of being asked questions about her and the attention that she gets compared to everyone else?
No, not really because in our sport there's ... I mean, she's like everyone else, you know, she falls off like everyone else.

Excellent - Small Talk has now fulfilled his journalistic contractual obligations for writing anything about equestrianism. Moving on, what sort of training did you do in preparation for the Games? Is it all just horse-based?
I have done some running, I sort of try to keep myself fit, but really I've got two children as well so by the time I've done them in the day and ridden all my horses I don't really feel like doing anything in the evening. You don't really build yourself up for the riding aspect aside from just doing it really.

With it being your first Games, are you more nervous or excited?
Umm ... it's very exciting to finally live your dream, you know? Everybody dreams of riding at the Olympics or competing at the Olympics and I just want to get going really.

Is it slightly annoying that the equestrian events are held in Hong Kong rather than Beijing?
Well, it is, I mean, you know, to us it's probably just like normal championship three-day events where all the riders are in the same hotel and everything, so I would have preferred obviously to have had the Olympic village and everything else. They are trying to make things like the Olympic village - we've got our own hotel and it's all sealed off to the public and only accredited officials can go in there - but it's not the same. I remember going to Atlanta and my ex-partner was riding there and we went into the Olympic village with all the basketball players and the gymnasts and it was just fantastic and I will miss staying on that side of things. Whether I keep going to London so I can experience that side of it, I don't know.

It would certainly be a lot more local for you.
Yeah, it would be a lot easier, it would!

Your horse is called Before I Do It. What's behind the name?
It was my ex-mother-in-law and all of her horses had 'Do It' in their name. We had May I Do It, I May Do It, Better I Do It, Believe me I Do It ... there's a superstition that you don't change a horse's name so she got stuck with it I'm afraid. Poor girl!

So in the events how much is down to the horse and how much of it is down to the rider - is it a 50-50 relationship?
Well, I mean, I couldn't do it without my horse and she couldn't do it without me. There are a lot of horses out there who can't make it to that level. My horse is physically … well, she's not built to do it but she's got a huge heart and that's what makes her do it for me. She tries so hard; even if she's struggling she'll keep trying for me. There's a lot of very, very talented horses that just don't have the heart and if they don't want to do it, one rider on top is not going to be able to make them to do it. So, it's a partnership really at the end of the day.

Do you end up have a quite close relationship with the horse, sort of sensing each others moves?
Yeah, definitely. I mean, I know her and she knows me. I know now that you don't go and hug her and trouble her until she's fit – she's very touchy and twitchy. You just leave her alone in her own space and you don't bother her. Other times you're walking in and she's pulling you and she wants some reassurance and a hug, so you go in and make a fuss of her.

So, you're the first Jamaican equestrian Olympian - that must be a source of real pride for you?
Well it is, it's lovely. I just wish I was in Jamaica to enjoy the coverage that I'm getting out there as well. My mum rings me all the time and tells me 'oh, an article came out' or 'I heard you on the radio'. But it is lovely.

You were born in Canada to a Jamaican mother and English father so who do you support when the football's on?
Well, Jamaica if we're in it, definitely. I call Jamaica my home even though I've lived in England for 18 years but Jamaica is always my home. Even though I was born in Canada I wouldn't consider myself Canadian. I still consider myself Jamaican.

How did you get into horse riding? It's not exactly the first thing you associate with the Caribbean.
Well, when we lived in Canada my dad took my two sisters and I to a riding school – I think they were six and five and I was three – and one couldn't stand the smell and the other was allergic to horses and I just loved it. I would drag my dad there every weekend to go and sit on these horses and eventually I convinced my dad to buy us a horse and he used to ride it and I would sit on a little cushion at the front. So I think it was definitely my dad's influence at the beginning since he was very supportive.

Don't you ever wake up and think 'I can't look at another horse today'?
No, I've never had that actually.

So you're very much in love with the sport?
Yeah, I can't imagine my life without horses. I couldn't live without them I have to say.

Right, enough of the horsey stuff, let's get down to serious business - what was the last CD you bought?
It's quite embarrassing … to tell the truth it was Neil Diamond. My Gran gave me a ticket for my birthday to see Neil Diamond so I thought I had better get myself up to date with his tunes. But my children were so appalled! When I played his music they wouldn't let me have my windows down in the car.

Tickets from your Gran? A likely story. What was the last book you read?
It would have to be a Danielle Steele. I only read trash - I don't read anything too serious.

Who would play you in a film of your life?
Oh God … it would have to be someone very gorgeous, so it makes me look nice. Maybe Julia Roberts or somebody really nice like that.

Who do you think would win a fight between a lion and a tiger?

[The line, very abruptly goes, dead. Small Talk wonders if the lion v tiger question has pushed things too far. Perhaps she's so enraged that she can't even bear to admonish Small Talk for his idiotic questions. She must be furious. Yet she seemed so nice. Phone her back. No, she's enraged. That'd only make things worse. Oh God, Small Talk what have you done? This is a nightm ...]

[Small Talk's phone rings]

[Not at all enraged or even the slightest bit furious] Sorry about that Small Talk, not sure what happened there. I'll say a lion - they're much stronger, I think.

Daniel Craig or Pierce Brosnan?
Pierce Brosnan.

Ah, the sophisticated choice. Cheese or chocolate?
Cheese. Any kind really.

And what would you put in Room 101?
Er ... [Small Talk explains the Orwellian concept, with reference to Paul Merton and Nick Hancock] ... I know what I would like to say but I don't think I can say it! My ex-husband! I had better not say that, I might get in big trouble for that one. Hopefully he won't read it.

Last of all, can you tell us a joke?
Oh God, no I'm terrible at jokes. The children always want me to tell jokes and I'm terrible, I always get it all mixed up. I can't tell you a joke I'm afraid.

Never mind, Sam. Thanks for taking the time to talk to us
No problem, Small Talk. Bye!

A Briton and four fellow activists are being deported from China today after unveiling a Free Tibet banner opposite a landmark new building for the state broadcaster.

Phil Kirk, 24, from Basingstoke, scaled an Olympics billboard facing the China Central Television (CCTV) site at around dawn and dropped a banner with both English and Chinese slogans.

A second climber, with Australian-Canadian nationality, and three American support people were also detained by police within half an hour.

Other members of Students for a Free Tibet have been unable to contact them but the state news agency Xinhua quoted local police as ordering them "to curtail their stay in China and leave the country earlier". All had entered on tourist visas.

Wang Wei, secretary-general of the Beijing Organising Committee for the Olympic Games, hit back at China's critics when asked about the protest.

"Maybe abroad you don't understand this issue. Tibet is an inalienable part of Chinese territory. Some there want a split and this is not good," he said in Chinese.

"I notice that most of the people in these demonstrations are non-Chinese so they don't understand. I don't think the media should encourage this. The Olympics are where you come to make friends and understand each other. Only with this can we resolve issues and not stir up trouble."

It was the first time Wang had responded to an English questioner in his native language, and the first time that he had commented on the political situation in Tibet beyond referring questions to the Chinese authorities.

The CCTV building, designed by Rem Koolhaas and engineered by Arup, will not be completed until later this year. But its distinctive twisted design and huge size has already made it an icon on the Beijing skyline. Locals refer to it as "the trousers", with its two leaning "legs" or towers which join together at the top.

"While the Chinese government has built a gleaming new building for its official mouthpiece and its public relations strategy has become more sophisticated, the propaganda it uses to maintain its iron-fisted control over Tibet remains the same," said Lhadon Tethong, executive director of Students for a Free Tibet.

It is the group's sixth protest within ten days in Beijing. Thirty-one members and supporters - including several Britons - have already been deported.

Keith Hackett's official answers:
1) The defender cannot assume what is about to happen: he has handled the ball while it is still live. It may seem harsh, but the law is clear: you must show him the yellow card for unsporting behaviour and award a penalty.
2) You cannot award a retake. However, if you agree that the dinosaur's action constituted deliberate outside distraction, then you should report the incident to the authorities after the game. I'd hope most referees wouldn't allow this to happen in the first place: you need to be vigilant at penalties to make sure the kick is taken fairly. In this case, ideally, if there is time before the kick is taken, you must intervene and stop play, and make sure the mascot moves away. The player is also within his rights to stop his run-up and ask you to deal with the dinosaur.
3) You cannot reverse your decision, and nor should you. It is the player's responsibility to keep his shirt on, so the second caution stands and he is sent off. He may like to have a word or two with his colleague after the game...

What was the Prague Spring, or the events of 1968 more generally? Their meaning, it seems, has become more, not less, debatable with the passage of time.

My generation was forged by protests and police truncheons, by the hopes generated not only by the Prague Spring, but also by the Polish student movement that March, the Paris events of May, and the first signs of Russian democracy voiced in the early books of Sakharov and Solzhenitsyn. For those of us imprisoned in Poland, the Prague Spring was a harbinger of hope. Even Poland's communist newspapers, read behind bars, somehow conveyed news of the great changes taking place in our neighbour to the south.

So I remember my shock when I learned about the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in August, and the trauma that lingered long after. On the 10th anniversary of that invasion, Václav Havel, Jacek Kuron, and I, along with other dissidents, met on the Czech-Polish border. There is a photograph of that occasion: future presidents, ministers, and parliamentarians who were at that time pursued by the police like common criminals.

These encounters were an extension of the climate of the Prague Spring. We all felt that we were creating something new, something that might, one day, turn out to be an important component of democracy in our countries.

And so it was. In August 1989, I proposed in the Polish diet a draft resolution apologising to the Czechs and Slovaks for Polish involvement in the 1968 invasion. I felt that a historical circle was being closed: the ideas of the Polish March and the Prague Spring, the ideas of our mountain meetings, were becoming political facts. Three months later, the Velvet Revolution began in Prague.

The main difference between the Prague Spring and the Velvet Revolution was that the former was mostly the work of Communist party members and others who wanted to bring about "socialism with a human face." As a result, some people nowadays dismiss the Prague Spring as a power struggle between communists. But there were many roads to – and through – communism, and many of them converged with national traditions.

Indeed, communism was attractive for many reasons, including the idea of universal justice and humanised social relations; a response to the great spiritual crisis after the first world war and, later, to the Nazis' genocide; and the conviction that western dominance of the world was nearing its end. Finally, in a world divided by Yalta, communism was, for some, the only realistic choice for central Europe.

In Czechoslovakia in 1968, communist reformers appealed to democratic ideals that were deeply rooted in the country's pre-second world war past. Alexander Dubcek, the leader of the Czechoslovak communists and the symbol of the Prague Spring, personified hope for democratic evolution, real pluralism, and a peaceful way to a state governed by law and respectful of human rights.

By contrast, in Poland, which had witnessed its own tentative opening in the March student movement, a nationalist-authoritarian faction exploited all that was intolerant and ignorant in Polish tradition, employing xenophobia and anti-intellectual rhetoric. Mieczyslaw Moczar, the Polish interior minister and leader of the nationalist faction, combined communist rhetoric with a language proper to fascist movements in order to mobilise the masses against the "cosmopolitan-liberal intelligentsia."

The Polish freedom movement of 1968 lost its confrontation with police violence; the Prague Spring was crushed by the armies of five Warsaw Pact members. But in both countries, 1968 gave birth to a new political consciousness. The Polish and Czech opposition movements that emerged only a few years later had their roots in the events of 1968.

Attitudes towards communism were always a controversial subject for the anticommunist opposition. Some rejected communism in all its forms. The majority though, in one way or another, had some contact with communism, through intellectual fascination, participation in state institutions, or the cold conviction that only by accepting the reality of life under communism could one do something useful for one's country. These people, "tainted by communism", constituted the majority of the participants in all revolts against the communist dictatorships.

There was, however, another category of people: the "careful and untainted", who absented themselves from the world of politics. They hated communism, but, convinced that the system could not be reformed, they avoided the democratic opposition. While others took risks or sat in jails, they functioned in official and legal structures.

One should not blame anyone today for such behaviour. But it is surprising when these people accuse participants in the Prague Spring and the democratic opposition of links with communism.

Communism was obviously an instrument of Soviet domination over conquered societies, but it was also a modus vivendi for large parts of these nations under the conditions in which they were obliged to live.

The Prague Spring appealed to elementary values: freedom, pluralism, tolerance, sovereignty, and rejection of the dictates of communist orthodoxy. When I recall these events after 40 years, I see not only revolt, but also the great illusion that it might be possible to outfox the Kremlin and painlessly move society from communism to democracy. This belief was naive, but it also underpinned a national awakening in which the potential for freedom found its voice.
